text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with one pot chicken and sausage
orzo that's right I really don't make a
lot of New Year's resolutions hey if
it's not broken don't fix it but one
thing I would like to do in the new year
is share more of these delicious one pot
recipes and above and beyond that you
only need one pot to make this these
type of dishes tend to be very simple
and fast to make so let's go ahead get
started with the browning of the sausage
so what we'll do is we'll place a pot
over medium-high heat and in just a
little bit of olive oil we're going to
brown some spicy Italian sausage and you
can use the bulk stuff if you want but
all I did was remove the casings from
two Italian sausages and sort of crumble
it up and like I said we're going to
want to brown this on medium high heat
and while we do we want to break it up
pretty fine and it was right about here
when I remembered what a bad job a
rounded wooden spoon does at crumbling
sausage meat so I made the executive
decision and switch to a flat edged
wooden spatula which did work way better
and what we'll do is we'll continue to
stir that and break it up and cook it
until it's fairly well browned at which
point it should look something very
close to this and when it does we can
stop and add our chicken so I'm gonna
add in two boneless skinless chicken
breasts that as you can see I cut into
bite-sized pieces and we'll stir that in
and cook it for about a minute we're not
really worried about browning it we just
wanted to mingle with those sausage fats
to pick up a little bit of that flavor
before we add the rest of the
ingredients and unlike the sausage this
chicken meat isn't seasoned so I will
tossed in a little bit of salt at this
point and I should mention I almost
always use chicken thigh for this but
this time I did go with the breast
because I know a lot of you're going to
use that anyway but anyway we'll get
into that later like I said we're going
to cook that chicken stirring for about
a minute at which point we could add our
chicken broth or of course chicken stock
in this contacts those things are
synonymous ensure if you have to use
water go ahead but only if you have to
do not use water on purpose and we'll
give that a stir and of course if there
was any caramelization on the bottom
that will have been too glazed and all
that tastiness will go into the liquid
and then besides the broth we also want
about 1/2 a cup of tomato sauce I really
don't want this to be a tomato sauce per
se but I do want a little bit here for
some color and some acidity to help
balance the other flavors
so we'll stir that in and we will raise
our heat to high and bring this up to a
simmer and while we're waiting for that
to happen let's go ahead and grab our
orzo and if you've never seen it before
it is a beautiful rice shaped pasta
that's also sometimes referred to as
melon seed pasta or so I've heard
oh yeah first pot of the new year don't
worry they get worse and what we'll do
as soon as our mixture comes to a simmer
is toss in our orzo along with some more
salts and we will stir that in and then
here's the deal what we'll do is we'll
lower our heat down to medium and we'll
cook this stirring for about 10 to 12
minutes or until the pasta is cooked and
most of the liquid is absorbed and if
everything goes according to plan those
two things should happen about the same
time and we don't necessarily have to
stir it constantly but we do in a
stirrer very often because this mixture
is going to start to thicken up and
because we are on medium heat and that's
bubbling pretty good we don't want it to
stick and burn to the bottom so keep it
moving keep an eye on it and this is
what mine look like about halfway
through you can see that pasta starting
to swell up and the mixture is
definitely getting thicker and by the
way something I'll mention on the blog
post but you might want to keep an extra
splash of broth handy in case all the
liquid gets absorbed before your pastas
tender which in that case you can throw
in an extra splash okay but anyway like
I said we're going to cook that for
about 10 to 12 minutes until our pasta
is just about tender and most of that
liquids been absorbed at which point it
should look something like this and of
course we could go just by looks but
that would be kind of crazy so it's a
much better idea would be to take a
spoon and actually try some so I gave
mine a taste and I confirm that it was
cooked perfectly which for me is about
95 percent tender because even though
we're going to turn off the heat and do
the final couple steps it's still going
to continue to cook a little bit but
anyway when we've decided our process
cooked long enough we're going to turn
off the heat and we're going to dump in
a nice handful of fresh Reggiano
parmesan and we'll stir that in and then
besides some nice real Italian cheese
I'm also going to add some fresh herb so
I'm going to toss in a little bit of
finely and freshly sliced chives and I
know those aren't technically an herb
but technically who cares and then we'll
also do some freshly chopped Italian
parsley
and once we stir that in we are pretty
much done and I say pretty much because
we're never really done until we give it
the final taste so we'll go ahead and
we'll sample a little bit
mostly checking for salt and once we're
happy with how that tastes we can go
ahead and dish that up and I know what
you're thinking that looks amazing let's
just eat it as is what we could but
let's not because how I really think you
should finish this is with a nice spoon
of fresh creamy ricotta cheese and not
only is this going to provide the always
important visual contrast but it will
also provide a contrast in texture and
temperature
so while optional that dollop is highly
recommended and we will top that with a
little more Italian parsley and that's
it our one pot chicken and sausage orzo
is done just a wonderfully comforting
dish and what's happened is that starch
from the pasta is combined with that
stock to make a very silky very smooth
sauce so I really do love this technique
and as I just mentioned that little bit
of ricotta it really does wonderful
things here just a beautiful cool and
creamy companion to our spicy sausage
meat and regarding the chicken as I
mentioned I do usually like to use
chicken thigh because I think it stays a
little moister but having said that this
was not bad with the breast although if
I do these breasts again I'd probably
Brown it first and then remove it from
the pan and then just put it back at the
end so it doesn't cook so long but
anyway I'll expand upon that on the blog
post at the moment I don't want to think
too much I would just prefer to eat this
cuz it's so good I mean I enjoyed this
so much even if it took 3 or 4 pots I
would still make it but it doesn't it
only takes one pot it's right in the
name ok
so I really do hope you give this a try
soon head over to food wishes calm for
all the ingredient amounts and more info
as usual and as always enjoy
you
